actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned. The next meeting is scheduled for 10:00 a.m. on March 28, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Jackson (IL) moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House has concluded all anticipated legislative business and has proceeded to Special Order speeches.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 415
actions-list.actionItem: 0 (Roll no. 164).

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1107 — "To direct the Secretary of State to take certain actions with respect to the labeling of the People's Republic of China as a developing country, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: (2/3 required): 413
actions-list.actionItem: 2 (Roll no. 163).
Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 1154 — "To combat forced organ harvesting and trafficking in persons for purposes of the removal of organs, and for other purposes."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on motions to suspend the rules and pass H.R. 1154, and H.R. 1107, as amended, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 27.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for approximately 6:30 P.M. today.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and pass the bill Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1189.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Mast moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1189 — "To require the development of a strategy to eliminate the availability to foreign adversaries of goods and technologies capable of supporting undersea cables, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1107.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Smith (NJ) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill, as amended. H.R. 1107 — "To direct the Secretary of State to take certain actions with respect to the labeling of the People's Republic of China as a developing country, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate, the Yeas and Nays were demanded and ordered. Pursuant to the provisions of clause 8, rule XX, the Chair announced that further proceedings on the motion would be postponed.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H.R. 1154.
Considered under suspension of the rules.
Mr. Smith (NJ) moved to suspend the rules and pass the bill. H.R. 1154 — "To combat forced organ harvesting and trafficking in persons for purposes of the removal of organs, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.
On motion to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution Agreed to by voice vote.
The House proceeded with forty minutes of debate on H. Con. Res. 15.
Considered under suspension of the rules.

Mr. Perry moved to suspend the rules and agree to the resolution. H. Con. Res. 15 — "Authorizing the use of the Capitol Grounds for the National Peace Officers Memorial Service and the National Honor Guard and Pipe Band Exhibition."
The Speaker announced that votes on suspensions, if ordered, will be postponed until a time to be announced.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 27.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

Pursuant to section 2 of the Migratory Bird Conservation Act (16 U.S.C. 715a), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Migratory Bird Conservation Commission: Mr. Wittman.

Pursuant to 22 U.S.C. 2903, and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Japan-United States Friendship Commission: Mr. Smith of Nebraska and Mr. Takano.

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Coast Guard Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 14 U.S.C. 1903(b), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Coast Guard Academy: Mr. Rutherford and Mrs. McClain.

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Military Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 10 U.S.C. 7455(a), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following members of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Military Academy: Mr. Womack and Mr. Davidson.
The House proceeded with one minute speeches.
The Chair designated Mr. Wilson of SC to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of March 27.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 2:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 2:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Mariannette Miller-Meeks to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
